definitions.definition: to make something/somebody clean using water and usually soap
definitions.sensetop: wash something/somebodywash something from somethingwash something/somebody + adj.

examples.text: These jeans need washing.
He always washes the car on Sundays.
to **wash your hands/hair/face**
Wash the fruit thoroughly before eating.
She washed the blood from his face.
The potatoes are washed clean without damaging the skins.
Hands need to be washed regularly with hot water.
She gently washed and dressed the wound.
the smell of freshly washed hair
He quickly washed his hands and face.
He washed his face.
If you wash the dishes, I'll dry.

definitions.definition: to make yourself clean using water and usually soap

examples.text: By this time we were already washed and dressed.
I washed and changed before going out.
Mick woke up, got washed and shaved, and put his work clothes on.
She was no longer able to wash herself.

definitions.definition: to be able to be washed without losing colour or being damaged

examples.text: This sweater washes well.

definitions.definition: to flow or carry something/somebody in a particular direction

examples.text: Water washed over the deck.
Pieces of the wreckage were **washed ashore**.
He was **washed overboard** by a huge wave.
The beach had been washed clean by the tide.

definitions.definition: to discuss your personal affairs in public, especially something embarrassing
to refuse to be responsible for or involved with somebody/something

examples.text: When her son was arrested again she washed her hands of him.
I’ve washed my hands of the whole sordid business.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody’s explanation, excuse, etc. is not true or that you/somebody else will not accept it

examples.text: That excuse simply won't wash with me.

wordOrigin: Old English wæscan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wassen, German waschen, also to water.
